Methylococcus capsulatus str. Bath is a species of methane-oxidizing bacteria, also known as methanotrophs, that was first isolated from the sediments of a warm spring in Bath, England. It is a Gram-negative, obligate aerobic bacterium that belongs to the class Gammaproteobacteria.

Methylococcus capsulatus str. Bath is characterized by its spherical or coccoid cell morphology, with a diameter ranging from 1 to 2 micrometers. It is capable of utilizing methane as its sole carbon and energy source, converting it to methanol and then to formaldehyde and carbon dioxide through a series of enzymatic reactions.

This species is known for its ability to produce a range of biotechnologically relevant compounds, such as single-cell proteins, biofuels, and various enzymes, making it an important organism in the field of biotechnology and environmental microbiology. Additionally, Methylococcus capsulatus str. Bath has been studied for its potential applications in bioremediation, as it can oxidize and degrade various halogenated organic compounds.

The genome of Methylococcus capsulatus str. Bath has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities, as well as the genetic mechanisms underlying its unique methane-oxidizing properties. This information has further expanded our understanding of the role of methanotrophs in the global carbon cycle and their potential for industrial and environmental applications.
